        This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<span class="line"><!---->This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<!----></span><br><br>Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<span class="line"><!---->Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<!----></span><br><br>The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <span class="line"><!---->The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <!----></span>ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64"><!---->ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<!----></a>, x64 asan build:<span class="line"><!---->, x64 asan build:<!----></span><br><br>diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<span class="line"><!---->index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<!----></span><br>--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo<v8::Value>* info) {<span class="line"><!---->@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo&lt;v8::Value&gt;* info) {<!----></span><br>   }<span class="line"><!---->   }<!----></span><br><br>   OnExit(isolate, false);<span class="line"><!---->   OnExit(isolate, false);<!----></span><br>+  for (int i = 0; i < 30000; i++) sleep(0);<span class="line"><!---->+  for (int i = 0; i &lt; 30000; i++) sleep(0);<!----></span><br>   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<span class="line"><!---->   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<!----></span><br> }<span class="line"><!----> }<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <span class="line"><!---->This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <!----></span><br><br>I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <span class="line"><!---->I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <!----></span><br><br>CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<span class="line"><!---->CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

      Steps to reproduce the problem:<b class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></b><br>ZDI-CAN-21781: Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->ZDI-CAN-21781: Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>-- CVSS -----------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- CVSS -----------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>8.8: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H<span class="line"><!---->8.8: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H<!----></span><br><br>-- ABSTRACT -------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- ABSTRACT -------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>Trend Micro's Zero Day Initiative has identified a vulnerability affecting the following products:<span class="line"><!---->Trend Micro's Zero Day Initiative has identified a vulnerability affecting the following products:<!----></span><br>Google - Chromium<span class="line"><!---->Google - Chromium<!----></span><br><br>-- VULNERABILITY DETAILS ------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- VULNERABILITY DETAILS ------------------------<!----></span><br>* Version tested:linux-release_d8-asan-no-inline-linux-release-v8-component-88967 + V8 compiled from commit <span class="line"><!---->* Version tested:linux-release_d8-asan-no-inline-linux-release-v8-component-88967 + V8 compiled from commit <!----></span>75a86fcbf108472efa847d067162c0d3262a4eb8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/75a86fcbf108472efa847d067162c0d3262a4eb8"><!---->75a86fcbf108472efa847d067162c0d3262a4eb8<!----></a><br>* Platform tested: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3208) + Ubuntu 22.04.1 64-bit<span class="line"><!---->* Platform tested: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3208) + Ubuntu 22.04.1 64-bit<!----></span><br><br>---<span         This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<span class="line"><!---->This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<!----></span><br><br>Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<span class="line"><!---->Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<!----></span><br><br>The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <span class="line"><!---->The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <!----></span>ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64"><!---->ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<!----></a>, x64 asan build:<span class="line"><!---->, x64 asan build:<!----></span><br><br>diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<span class="line"><!---->index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<!----></span><br>--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo<v8::Value>* info) {<span class="line"><!---->@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo&lt;v8::Value&gt;* info) {<!----></span><br>   }<span class="line"><!---->   }<!----></span><br><br>   OnExit(isolate, false);<span class="line"><!---->   OnExit(isolate, false);<!----></span><br>+  for (int i = 0; i < 30000; i++) sleep(0);<span class="line"><!---->+  for (int i = 0; i &lt; 30000; i++) sleep(0);<!----></span><br>   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<span class="line"><!---->   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<!----></span><br> }<span class="line"><!----> }<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <span class="line"><!---->This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <!----></span><br><br>I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <span class="line"><!---->I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <!----></span><br><br>CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<span class="line"><!---->CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      Steps to reproduce the problem:<b class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></b><br>ZDI-CAN-21781: Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->ZDI-CAN-21781: Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>-- CVSS -----------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- CVSS -----------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>8.8: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H<span class="line"><!---->8.8: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H<!----></span><br><br>-- ABSTRACT -------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- ABSTRACT -------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>Trend Micro's Zero Day Initiative has identified a vulnerability affecting the following products:<span class="line"><!---->Trend Micro's Zero Day Initiative has identified a vulnerability affecting the following products:<!----></span><br>Google - Chromium<span class="line"><!---->Google - Chromium<!----></span><br><br>-- VULNERABILITY DETAILS ------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- VULNERABILITY DETAILS ------------------------<!----></span><br>* Version tested:linux-release_d8-asan-no-inline-linux-release-v8-component-88967 + V8 compiled from commit <span class="line"><!---->* Version tested:linux-release_d8-asan-no-inline-linux-release-v8-component-88967 + V8 compiled from commit <!----></span>75a86fcbf108472efa847d067162c0d3262a4eb8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" 19045.3208) + Ubuntu 22.04.1 64-bit<span class="line"><!---->* Platform tested: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3208) + Ubuntu 22.04.1 64-bit<!----></span><br><br>---<span         I'm partially triaging on the assumption that the report is valid, but so far neither ClusterFuzz nor I am having success with repro using the updated POC, even when repeatedly retrying the suggested 89006 d8 ASan build on a nearly identical x64 Linux test environment. <span class="line"><!---->I'm partially triaging on the assumption that the report is valid, but so far neither ClusterFuzz nor I am having success with repro using the updated POC, even when repeatedly retrying the suggested 89006 d8 ASan build on a nearly identical x64 Linux test environment. <!----></span><br><br>To troubleshoot, I'm manually feeding in the POC at the d8 shell, where the following line causes d8 to abort without a discernible error. <span class="line"><!---->To troubleshoot, I'm manually feeding in the POC at the d8 shell, where the following line causes d8 to abort without a discernible error. <!----></span><br><br>> const worker = new Worker(func, {"type": "function"});<span class="line"><!---->&gt; const worker = new Worker(func, {"type": "function"});<!----></span><br><br>However, when run within Chrome's JavaScript console, the same line results in the following error: <span class="line"><!---->However, when run within Chrome's JavaScript console, the same line results in the following error: <!----></span><br><br>> Uncaught TypeError: Failed to construct 'Worker': Failed to read the 'type' property from 'WorkerOptions': The provided value 'function' is not a valid enum value of type WorkerType. at <anonymous>:1:16<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Uncaught TypeError: Failed to construct 'Worker': Failed to read the 'type' property from 'WorkerOptions': The provided value 'function' is not a valid enum value of type WorkerType. at &lt;anonymous&gt;:1:16<!----></span><br><br>Given these errors it's currently difficult to see how the provided POC could achieve intended execution and subsequently result in the ASan crash described above. <span class="line"><!---->Given these errors it's currently difficult to see how the provided POC could achieve intended execution and subsequently result in the ASan crash described above. <!----></span><br><br>I'm without access to a Windows machine today, so I can't try the pagehead suggestion, but we'll keep tinkering. Any further guidance to assist with repro is appreciated. <span class="line"><!---->I'm without access to a Windows machine today, so I can't try the pagehead suggestion, but we'll keep tinkering.           -Blink>JavaScript Blink>JavaScript>Runtime
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Owner:</strong>
          
          ahaas@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          cbruni@chromium.org ishell@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Components:</strong>
          
          -Blink&gt;JavaScript Blink&gt;JavaScript&gt;Runtime
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<span class="line"><!---->This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<!----></span><br><br>Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<span class="line"><!---->Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<!----></span><br><br>The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <span class="line"><!---->The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <!----></span>ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64"><!---->ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<!----></a>, x64 asan build:<span class="line"><!---->, x64 asan build:<!----></span><br><br>diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<span class="line"><!---->index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<!----></span><br>--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo<v8::Value>* info) {<span class="line"><!---->@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo&lt;v8::Value&gt;* info) {<!----></span><br>   }<span class="line"><!---->   }<!----></span><br><br>   OnExit(isolate, false);<span class="line"><!---->   OnExit(isolate, false);<!----></span><br>+  for (int i = 0; i < 30000; i++) sleep(0);<span class="line"><!---->+  for (int i = 0; i &lt; 30000; i++) sleep(0);<!----></span><br>   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<span class="line"><!---->   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<!----></span><br> }<span class="line"><!----> }<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <span class="line"><!---->This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <!----></span><br><br>I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <span class="line"><!---->I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <!----></span><br><br>CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<span class="line"><!---->CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      </div>
      Steps to reproduce the problem:<b class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></b><br>ZDI-CAN-21781: Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->ZDI-CAN-21781: Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>-- CVSS -----------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- CVSS -----------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>8.8: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H<span class="line"><!---->8.8: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H<!----></span><br><br>-- ABSTRACT -------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- ABSTRACT -------------------------------------<!----></span><br><br>Trend Micro's Zero Day Initiative has identified a vulnerability affecting the following products:<span class="line"><!---->Trend Micro's Zero Day Initiative has identified a vulnerability affecting the following products:<!----></span><br>Google - Chromium<span class="line"><!---->Google - Chromium<!----></span><br><br>-- VULNERABILITY DETAILS ------------------------<span class="line"><!---->-- VULNERABILITY DETAILS ------------------------<!----></span><br>* Version tested:linux-release_d8-asan-no-inline-linux-release-v8-component-88967 + V8 compiled from commit <span class="line"><!---->* Version tested:linux-release_d8-asan-no-inline-linux-release-v8-component-88967 + V8 compiled from commit <!----></span>75a86fcbf108472efa847d067162c0d3262a4eb8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/75a86fcbf108472efa847d067162c0d3262a4eb8"><!---->75a86fcbf108472efa847d067162c0d3262a4eb8<!----></a><br>* Platform tested: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3208) + Ubuntu 22.04.1 64-bit<span class="line"><!---->* Platform tested: Windows 10 Enterprise x64 version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3208) + Ubuntu 22.04.1 64-bit<!----></span><br><br>---<span class="line"><!---->---<!----></span><br><br>Problem Description:<b class="line"><!---->Problem Description:<!----></b><br>Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<span class="line"><!---->Google Chromium V8 postMessage Handling Use-After-Free Remote Code Execution Vulnerability<!----></span><br><br>Additional Comments:<b         I'm partially triaging on the assumption that the report is valid, but so far neither ClusterFuzz nor I am having success with repro using the updated POC, even when repeatedly retrying the suggested 89006 d8 ASan build on a nearly identical x64 Linux test environment. <span class="line"><!---->I'm partially triaging on the assumption that the report is valid, but so far neither ClusterFuzz nor I am having success with repro using the updated POC, even when repeatedly retrying the suggested 89006 d8 ASan build on a nearly identical x64 Linux test environment. <!----></span><br><br>To troubleshoot, I'm manually feeding in the POC at the d8 shell, where the following line causes d8 to abort without a discernible error. <span class="line"><!---->To troubleshoot, I'm manually feeding in the POC at the d8 shell, where the following line causes d8 to abort without a discernible error. <!----></span><br><br>> const worker = new Worker(func, {"type": "function"});<span class="line"><!---->&gt; const worker = new Worker(func, {"type": "function"});<!----></span><br><br>However, when run within Chrome's JavaScript console, the same line results in the following error: <span class="line"><!---->However, when run within Chrome's JavaScript console, the same line results in the following error: <!----></span><br><br>> Uncaught TypeError: Failed to construct 'Worker': Failed to read the 'type' property from 'WorkerOptions': The provided value 'function' is not a valid enum value of type WorkerType. at <anonymous>:1:16<span class="line"><!---->&gt; Uncaught TypeError: Failed to construct 'Worker': Failed to read the 'type' property from 'WorkerOptions': The provided value 'function' is not a valid enum value of type WorkerType. at &lt;anonymous&gt;:1:16<!----></span><br><br>Given these errors it's currently difficult to see how the provided POC could achieve intended execution and subsequently result in the ASan crash described above. <span class="line"><!---->Given these errors it's currently difficult to see how the provided POC could achieve intended execution and subsequently result in the ASan crash described above. <!----></span><br><br>I'm without access to a Windows machine today, so I can't try the pagehead suggestion, but we'll keep tinkering. Any further guidance to assist with repro is appreciated. <span class="line"><!---->I'm without access to a Windows machine today, so I can't try the pagehead suggestion, but we'll keep tinkering.           <br>

      </div><br>
    
        
      
        This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<span class="line"><!---->This particular issue is related to d8 and implementation of Shell::QuitOnce - main thread is executing JS code while the Isolate was already destroyed by the call to `this.testRunner.quit();` from the worker thread. I'm not sure if a similar issue could happen in Chrome.<!----></span><br><br>Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<span class="line"><!---->Assigning to ahaas@ who worked on task manager implementation vs Isolate shut down.<!----></span><br><br>The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <span class="line"><!---->The following change helps to reproduce the issue on <!----></span>ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64"><!---->ed93bef7ab786d5367c2ae7882922c23aa0eda64<!----></a>, x64 asan build:<span class="line"><!---->, x64 asan build:<!----></span><br><br>diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->diff --git a/src/d8/d8.cc b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<span class="line"><!---->index c4b8f7ecda6..ecd60169779 100644<!----></span><br>--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->--- a/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<span class="line"><!---->+++ b/src/d8/d8.cc<!----></span><br>@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo<v8::Value>* info) {<span class="line"><!---->@@ -2991,6 +2991,7 @@ void Shell::QuitOnce(v8::FunctionCallbackInfo&lt;v8::Value&gt;* info) {<!----></span><br>   }<span class="line"><!---->   }<!----></span><br><br>   OnExit(isolate, false);<span class="line"><!---->   OnExit(isolate, false);<!----></span><br>+  for (int i = 0; i < 30000; i++) sleep(0);<span class="line"><!---->+  for (int i = 0; i &lt; 30000; i++) sleep(0);<!----></span><br>   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<span class="line"><!---->   base::OS::ExitProcess(exit_code);<!----></span><br> }<span class="line"><!----> }<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <span class="line"><!---->This particular POC doesn't seem exploitable in Chrome because it appears to require d8's specific use of v8::shell to set up the UaF. <!----></span><br><br>I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <span class="line"><!---->I'm less certain whether Chrome ever holds onto an task after the associated Worker is freed, which may be worth exploring for variants present in Chrome, and I believe abusing object life cycle issues during Worker destruction is already a known bug pattern. However, if found, those would be different bugs than the one described here, so for the purposes of Chrome Security triage I'm inclined to convert this report from a Security Bug into a normal Bug. <!----></span><br><br>CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<span class="line"><!---->CCing V8 Security explicitly so they get an opportunity to correct me if I've incorrectly jumped to any conclusions.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.

          position: relative;

        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;

           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */

        for LitElement.

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
